CN.content:
Please identify the "Material Name" entities in the following paragraph.

Paragraph: The decent hole mobilities of both copolymers can be attributed to high crystallinity of the copolymers due to the highly coplanar structure of anthracene and DPP. It is also understood that the 3-fold higher chargecarrier mobility of PTATDPP than that of PTAFDPP arises from its stronger π-π stacking with a shorter d 010 , as discussed above. When the photovoltaic properties of copolymers are measured using PC71BM as an electron acceptor , it is found that the optimum blend ratio of polymer : PC71BM is 1 : 2 to afford the best PCE of both copolymers with the conventional device architecture of ITO / PEDOT : PSS / polymer : PC71BM / Ca / Al ( Fig. S2 and Table S1 † ). The best PCE was also achieved when o-dichlorobenzene was used as a solvent and the optimum thickness for the active layer was ca. 90 nm. The current density - voltage ( J-V ) characteristics of the optimized solar cells are shown in Fig. 4 , and the relevant photovoltaic parameters of the devices are summarized in Tables 2 and S2. † PTATDPP showed a best PCE of 6.69% ( V OC = 0.80 V , J SC = 12.3 mA cm^-2 , FF = 0.68 ) , while PTAFDPP showed a best PCE of 5.02% ( V OC = 0.76 V , J SC = 11.2 mA cm^-2 , FF = 0.59 ). Both copolymers showed higher V OC s than other DPP - based copolymers due to their low - lying HOMO energy levels. Both copolymers also exhibited high J SC s and FFs , indicating their decent ability for charge generation and transport. Therefore , the TA unit is a promising electron - donating unit for low band - gap copolymers with a low - lying HOMO energy level. When the PSC devices were fabricated with an inverted architecture ( ITO / ZnO / polymer : PC71BM / MoO 3 / Ag ) in order to further improve the photovoltaic performance , the PCEs of PTATDPP and PTAFDPP - based devices were improved to 7.02% and 5.22% , respectively ( Fig. 4b , Tables 2 and S2 † ) , mainly due to enhanced J SC s ( V OC s and FFs were not changed significantly ). It is noteworthy here that the PCE of over 7% of PTATDPP is the highest efficiency of anthracene - based low band - gap conjugated copolymers. In spite of the same band - gap of the two copolymers , PTATDPP shows slightly higher J SC and FF than PTAFDPP ( Fig. S3 † ). This can be ascribed to the closely packed microstructures of PTATDPP and thereby its high charge - carrier mobility than PTAFDPP. When the crystal structures of blend films of the copolymers with PC71BM were examined by XRD , the PTATDPP / PC71BM blend had strong and intense ( 100 ) diffraction while the PTAFDPP / PC71BM blend showed weak and broad ( 100 ) diffraction ( Fig. 2b ).

Let's think step by step.

Sure! Let's identify the "Material Name" entities in the paragraph:

1. copolymers
2. anthracene
3. DPP (dialkylphenylene)
4. PC71BM (polymeric phenyl-C61 butyric acid methyl ester)
5. PEDOT (poly(3,4-ethylenedioxythiophene))
6. PSS (polystyrene sulfonate)
7. Ca (calcium)
8. Al (aluminum)
9. ITO (indium tin oxide)
10. ZnO (zinc oxide)
11. MoO3 (molybdenum oxide)
12. Ag (silver)

These are the entities mentioned in the paragraph that are likely to be material names.
Please remove irrelevant entities and only keep the entities that clearly refer to Material Name.

Of course! Here are the material names mentioned in the paragraph:

1. copolymers
2. PC71BM

These are the only material names mentioned in the paragraph.

Please present the valid entities as a Markdown table with one column "Material Name".

Make sure to present the entities precisely in the same words as in the original paragraph.

Certainly! Here are the material names mentioned in the paragraph, presented in a Markdown table with one column "Material Name":

| Material Name |
| --- |
| copolymers |
| PC71BM |

I hope this helps! Let me know if you have any further questions.

Paragraph: The decent hole mobilities of both copolymers can be attributed to high crystallinity of the copolymers due to the highly coplanar structure of anthracene and DPP. It is also understood that the 3-fold higher chargecarrier mobility of PTATDPP than that of PTAFDPP arises from its stronger π-π stacking with a shorter d 010 , as discussed above. When the photovoltaic properties of copolymers are measured using PC71BM as an electron acceptor , it is found that the optimum blend ratio of polymer : PC71BM is 1 : 2 to afford the best PCE of both copolymers with the conventional device architecture of ITO / PEDOT : PSS / polymer : PC71BM / Ca / Al ( Fig. S2 and Table S1 † ). The best PCE was also achieved when o-dichlorobenzene was used as a solvent and the optimum thickness for the active layer was ca. 90 nm. The current density - voltage ( J-V ) characteristics of the optimized solar cells are shown in Fig. 4 , and the relevant photovoltaic parameters of the devices are summarized in Tables 2 and S2. † PTATDPP showed a best PCE of 6.69% ( V OC = 0.80 V , J SC = 12.3 mA cm^-2 , FF = 0.68 ) , while PTAFDPP showed a best PCE of 5.02% ( V OC = 0.76 V , J SC = 11.2 mA cm^-2 , FF = 0.59 ). Both copolymers showed higher V OC s than other DPP - based copolymers due to their low - lying HOMO energy levels. Both copolymers also exhibited high J SC s and FFs , indicating their decent ability for charge generation and transport. Therefore , the TA unit is a promising electron - donating unit for low band - gap copolymers with a low - lying HOMO energy level. When the PSC devices were fabricated with an inverted architecture ( ITO / ZnO / polymer : PC71BM / MoO 3 / Ag ) in order to further improve the photovoltaic performance , the PCEs of PTATDPP and PTAFDPP - based devices were improved to 7.02% and 5.22% , respectively ( Fig. 4b , Tables 2 and S2 † ) , mainly due to enhanced J SC s ( V OC s and FFs were not changed significantly ). It is noteworthy here that the PCE of over 7% of PTATDPP is the highest efficiency of anthracene - based low band - gap conjugated copolymers. In spite of the same band - gap of the two copolymers , PTATDPP shows slightly higher J SC and FF than PTAFDPP ( Fig. S3 † ). This can be ascribed to the closely packed microstructures of PTATDPP and thereby its high charge - carrier mobility than PTAFDPP. When the crystal structures of blend films of the copolymers with PC71BM were examined by XRD , the PTATDPP / PC71BM blend had strong and intense ( 100 ) diffraction while the PTAFDPP / PC71BM blend showed weak and broad ( 100 ) diffraction ( Fig. 2b ).

Let's think step by step.

1. Materials mentioned in the paragraph are:
 * Copolymers (PTATDPP and PTAFDPP)
 * Anthracene
 * DPP (dialkoxyphenylene)
 * PC71BM (polymeric phenyl-C61 butyric acid methyl ester)
 * PEDOT (poly(3,4-ethylenedioxythiophene))

2. Property names mentioned in the paragraph are:

 * Crystallinity
 * Charge-carrier mobility
 * Photovoltaic properties
 * Optimum blend ratio
 * Solvent
 * Thickness
 * Voltage-current density (J-V) characteristics
 * Photovoltaic parameters
 * Efficiency
 * Band gap
 * HOMO energy level
 * J SC (current density-voltage)
 * FF (fill factor)
 * PCE (power conversion efficiency)
 * V OC (open-circuit voltage)
 * J SC (short-circuit current)
 * FF (fill factor)

Note: Some of these properties are mentioned in the context of the copolymers, while others are mentioned in the context of the solar cells or the materials used in the solar cells.

Let's think step by step.

1. Values of material properties:

a. Crystallinity: Not explicitly mentioned in the passage.

b. Charge carrier mobility: Not explicitly mentioned in the passage.

c. HOMO energy level: 0.80 V (for PTATDPP) and 0.76 V (for PTAFDPP)

d. Lying HOMO energy level: Low - lying (for both copolymers)

e. V OC: 0.80 V (for PTATDPP) and 0.76 V (for PTAFDPP)

f. J SC: 12.3 mA cm^-2 (for PTATDPP) and 11.2 mA cm^-2 (for PTAFDPP)

g. FF: 0.68 (for PTATDPP) and 0.59 (for PTAFDPP)

h. PCE: 6.69% (for PTATDPP) and 5.02% (for PTAFDPP)

i. Inverted architecture PCE: 7.02% (for PTATDPP) and 5.22% (for PTAFDPP)

j. Highest efficiency of anthracene - based low band - gap conjugated copolymers: 7.02% (for PTATDPP)

k. Closely packed microstructures: PTATDPP

l. XRD diffraction: (100) diffraction for PTATDPP and weak and broad (100) diffraction for PTAFDPP.
